properties.author: Johnson, Philip M and Zhang, Shaoxuan and Senin, Pavel

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.
properties.editor: James Kijas

properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

@Article{woyke2009assembling,
  author    = {Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and Jos{\'{e}} M. Gonz{\'{a}}lez and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas},

  year      = {2009},
  month     = {apr},
  number    = {4},
  pages     = {1-10},
  volume    = {4},
  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91\% and 78\%, respectively. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
  editor    = {Niyaz Ahmed},

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.

properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)
properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.

@Article{chain2017enabling,
  author       = {Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain},
  title        = {Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data},
  year         = {2017},
  issn         = {2331-8325},
  month        = {5},
  volume       = {7},
  abstractnote = {EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.},
  doi          = {10.21769/bioprotoc.2622},
  institution  = {Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)},
  url          = {https://www.osti.gov/biblio/1357891},
}

@TechReport{chain2017edge,
  author       = {Patrick Sam Guy Chain and Karen Walston Davenport and Po-E Li and Chien-Chi Lo and Yan Xu and Pavel Senin and Migun Shakya and Sanaa Afroz Ahmed and Theron C. Hamilton and Kimberly A. Bishop-Lilly and Joseph J. Anderson and Logan J. Voegtly and Casandra W. Philipson},
  institution  = {Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)},
  title        = {{EDGE} 2017 R{\&}D 100 Entry with Appendix},
  year         = {2017},
  month        = {4},
  abstractnote = {Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately $3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than $1,000.},
  doi          = {10.2172/1352402},
  place        = {United States},
  publisher    = {Office of Scientific and Technical Information ({OSTI})},
  url          = {https://www.osti.gov/biblio/1352402},
}

@Article{rupp2015point,
  author    = {Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and C{\'{e}}cile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp},
  journal   = {{PLOS} Genetics},
  title     = {A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model},
  year      = {2015},
  month     = {12},
  number    = {12},
  pages     = {1-19},
  volume    = {11},
  abstract  = {Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
  editor    = {James Kijas},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
}

@Article{woyke2009assembling,
  author    = {Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and Jos{\'{e}} M. Gonz{\'{a}}lez and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas},
  journal   = {{PLoS} {ONE}},
  title     = {Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time},
  year      = {2009},
  month     = {apr},
  number    = {4},
  pages     = {1-10},
  volume    = {4},
  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91\% and 78\%, respectively. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
  editor    = {Niyaz Ahmed},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
}

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.

properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

  author    = {Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and C{\'{e}}cile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp},
  journal   = {{PLOS} Genetics},
  title     = {A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model},
  year      = {2015},
  month     = {12},
  number    = {12},
  pages     = {1-19},
  volume    = {11},
  abstract  = {Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
  editor    = {James Kijas},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
}

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.
properties.publisher: Office of Scientific and Technical Information ({OSTI})

properties.author: Crystal Chen and Arnold P. Boedihardjo and Brian S. Jenkins and Charlotte L. Ellison and Jessica Lin and Pavel Senin and Tim Oates
properties.booktitle: International Symposium on Spatial and Temporal Databases
properties.title: STAVIS 2.0: Mining Spatial Trajectories via Motifs

properties.author: Germain Forestier and François Petitjean and Pavel Senin and Fabien Despinoy and Pierre Jannin
properties.booktitle: Artificial Intelligence in Medicine - 16th Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Medicine, {AIME} 2017, Vienna, Austria, June 21-24, 2017, Proceedings
properties.title: Discovering Discriminative and Interpretable Patterns for Surgical Motion Analysis
properties.editor: Annette ten Teije and Christian Popow and John H. Holmes and Lucia Sacchi

properties.author: Germain Forestier and François Petitjean and Pavel Senin and Laurent Riffaud and Pierre{-}Louis Hénaux and Pierre Jannin
properties.title: Finding discriminative and interpretable patterns in sequences of surgical activities

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

@Article{rupp2015point,
  author    = {Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and C{\'{e}}cile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp},
  journal   = {{PLOS} Genetics},
  title     = {A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model},
  year      = {2015},
  month     = {12},
  number    = {12},
  pages     = {1-19},
  volume    = {11},
  abstract  = {Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
  editor    = {James Kijas},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
}

  title        = {Identification et caract{\'e}risation d'une mutation dans le g{\`e}ne SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associ{\'e}e {\`a} la sensibilit{\'e} aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers},

@Article{woyke2009assembling,
  author    = {Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and Jos{\'{e}} M. Gonz{\'{a}}lez and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas},
  journal   = {{PLoS} {ONE}},
  title     = {Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time},
  year      = {2009},
  month     = {apr},
  number    = {4},
  pages     = {1-10},
  volume    = {4},
  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91\% and 78\%, respectively. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
  editor    = {Niyaz Ahmed},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
}

properties.author: Johnson, Philip M and Zhang, Shaoxuan and Senin, Pavel

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.

properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

@Article{rupp2015point,
  author    = {Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and C{\'{e}}cile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp},
  journal   = {{PLOS} Genetics},
  title     = {A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model},
  year      = {2015},
  month     = {12},
  number    = {12},
  pages     = {1-19},
  volume    = {11},
  abstract  = {Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
  editor    = {James Kijas},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
}

@Article{woyke2009assembling,
  author    = {Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and Jos{\'{e}} M. Gonz{\'{a}}lez and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas},
  journal   = {{PLoS} {ONE}},
  title     = {Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time},
  year      = {2009},
  month     = {apr},
  number    = {4},
  pages     = {1-10},
  volume    = {4},
  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91\% and 78\%, respectively. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
  editor    = {Niyaz Ahmed},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
}

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.booktitle: 22. Rencontres Recherches Ruminants
properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.
properties.editor: James Kijas

properties.title: Software Trajectory Analysis: An empirically based method for automated software process discovery

properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.
properties.publisher: Office of Scientific and Technical Information ({OSTI})

properties.title: Finding discriminative and interpretable patterns in sequences of surgical activities

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.

properties.title: Identification et caractérisation d'une mutation dans le gène SOCS2 (Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2) associée à la sensibilité aux mammites chez les ovins laitiers

properties.author: Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and Cécile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp
properties.title: A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model
properties.abstract: Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.

properties.title: {EDGE} 2017 R&D 100 Entry with Appendix
properties.abstractnote: Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately 3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than 1,000.

properties.author: Casandra Philipson and Karen Davenport and Logan Voegtly and Chien-Chi Lo and Po-E. Li and Yan Xu and Migun Shakya and Regina Cer and Kimberly Bishop-Lilly and Theron Hamilton and Patrick Chain
properties.title: Brief Protocol for EDGE Bioinformatics: Analyzing Microbial and Metagenomic NGS Data
properties.abstractnote: EDGE bioinformatics was developed to help biologists process Next Generation Sequencing data (in the form of raw FASTQ files), even if they have little to no bioinformatics expertise. EDGE is a highly integrated and interactive web-based platform that is capable of running many of the standard analyses that biologists require for viral, bacterial/archaeal, and metagenomic samples. EDGE provides the following analytical workflows: quality trimming and host removal, assembly and annotation, comparisons against known references, taxonomy classification of reads and contigs, whole genome SNP-based phylogenetic analysis, and PCR analysis. EDGE provides an intuitive web-based interface for user input, allows users to visualize and interact with selected results (e.g. JBrowse genome browser), and generates a final detailed PDF report. Results in the form of tables, text files, graphic files, and PDFs can be downloaded. A user management system allows tracking of an individual’s EDGE runs, along with the ability to share, post publicly, delete, or archive their results.
properties.institution: Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)

@TechReport{chain2017edge,
  author       = {Patrick Sam Guy Chain and Karen Walston Davenport and Po-E Li and Chien-Chi Lo and Yan Xu and Pavel Senin and Migun Shakya and Sanaa Afroz Ahmed and Theron C. Hamilton and Kimberly A. Bishop-Lilly and Joseph J. Anderson and Logan J. Voegtly and Casandra W. Philipson},
  institution  = {Los Alamos National Lab.(LANL), Los Alamos, NM (United States)},
  title        = {{EDGE} 2017 R{\&}D 100 Entry with Appendix},
  year         = {2017},
  month        = {4},
  abstractnote = {Diabetes, infertility, cancer, and Alzheimer’s disease—the key to one day preventing or even curing such afflictions and diseases (both infectious and genetically driven) may be locked in our own genetic code and the code of microorganisms that inhabit our bodies. The study of this code, known as genomics, has recently become much more promising as a result of two things: (1) vast improvements in high-throughput, nextgeneration sequencing (NSG), and (2) an exponential decrease in the cost of such sequencing. For example, it originally cost approximately $3 billion to sequence the human genome; today, this genome could be resequenced for less than $1,000.},
  doi          = {10.2172/1352402},

}

@Article{rupp2015point,
  author    = {Rachel Rupp and Pavel Senin and Julien Sarry and Charlotte Allain and Christian Tasca and Laeticia Ligat and David Portes and Florent Woloszyn and Olivier Bouchez and Guillaume Tabouret and Mathieu Lebastard and C{\'{e}}cile Caubet and Gilles Foucras and Gwenola Tosser-Klopp},
  journal   = {{PLOS} Genetics},
  title     = {A Point Mutation in Suppressor of Cytokine Signalling 2 (Socs2) Increases the Susceptibility to Inflammation of the Mammary Gland while Associated with Higher Body Weight and Size and Higher Milk Production in a Sheep Model},
  year      = {2015},
  month     = {12},
  number    = {12},
  pages     = {1-19},
  volume    = {11},
  abstract  = {Author Summary Mastitis is an inflammation of the mammary gland mainly caused by invading bacteria. Ruminants show natural variability in their predisposition to mastitis, and therefore provide unique models for study of the genetics and physiology of host response to bacterial infection. A genome-wide association study was conducted in a dairy sheep population for milk somatic cell counts as a proxy for mastitis. Fine mapping, using whole genome sequencing, led to the identification of a mutation in the Suppressor of Cytokine Signaling 2 gene (socs2). This mutation was shown to cause a loss of functional activity of the SOCS2 protein, which suggested impairment of feedback control of the JAK/STAT signaling pathways in susceptible animals. Additionally, size, weight and milk production were increased in animals carrying the susceptible variant suggesting a pleiotropic effect of the gene on production versus health traits. Results gave strong evidence of the role of SOCS2 in the host’s inflammation of the udder and provided new insights into the key mechanisms underlying the genetic control of mastitis.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
  editor    = {James Kijas},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1005629},
}

@Article{woyke2009assembling,
  author    = {Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and Jos{\'{e}} M. Gonz{\'{a}}lez and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas},
  journal   = {{PLoS} {ONE}},
  title     = {Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time},
  year      = {2009},
  month     = {apr},
  number    = {4},
  pages     = {1-10},
  volume    = {4},
  abstract  = {The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91\% and 78\%, respectively. Only 0.24\% of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.},
  doi       = {10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
  editor    = {Niyaz Ahmed},
  publisher = {Public Library of Science},
  url       = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0005299},
}

Tanja Woyke and Gary Xie and Alex Copeland and José M. González and Cliff Han and Hajnalka Kiss and Jimmy H. Saw and Pavel Senin and Chi Yang and Sourav Chatterji and Jan-Fang Cheng and Jonathan A. Eisen and Michael E. Sieracki and Ramunas Stepanauskas
properties.title: Assembling the Marine Metagenome, One Cell at a Time
properties.abstract: The difficulty associated with the cultivation of most microorganisms and the complexity of natural microbial assemblages, such as marine plankton or human microbiome, hinder genome reconstruction of representative taxa using cultivation or metagenomic approaches. Here we used an alternative, single cell sequencing approach to obtain high-quality genome assemblies of two uncultured, numerically significant marine microorganisms. We employed fluorescence-activated cell sorting and multiple displacement amplification to obtain hundreds of micrograms of genomic DNA from individual, uncultured cells of two marine flavobacteria from the Gulf of Maine that were phylogenetically distant from existing cultured strains. Shotgun sequencing and genome finishing yielded 1.9 Mbp in 17 contigs and 1.5 Mbp in 21 contigs for the two flavobacteria, with estimated genome recoveries of about 91%and 78%, respectively. Only 0.24%of the assembling sequences were contaminants and were removed from further analysis using rigorous quality control. In contrast to all cultured strains of marine flavobacteria, the two single cell genomes were excellent Global Ocean Sampling (GOS) metagenome fragment recruiters, demonstrating their numerical significance in the ocean. The geographic distribution of GOS recruits along the Northwest Atlantic coast coincided with ocean surface currents. Metabolic reconstruction indicated diverse potential energy sources, including biopolymer degradation, proteorhodopsin photometabolism, and hydrogen oxidation. Compared to cultured relatives, the two uncultured flavobacteria have small genome sizes, few non-coding nucleotides, and few paralogous genes, suggesting adaptations to narrow ecological niches. These features may have contributed to the abundance of the two taxa in specific regions of the ocean, and may have hindered their cultivation. We demonstrate the power of single cell DNA sequencing to generate reference genomes of uncultured taxa from a complex microbial community of marine bacterioplankton. A combination of single cell genomics and metagenomics enabled us to analyze the genome content, metabolic adaptations, and biogeography of these taxa.
